Article.Abstract: In order to identify T cell epitopes within the Mycobacterium leprae 45-kD serine-rich antigen, we analysed responses to overlapping 17-mer peptides encompassing the whole antigen in non-exposed UK controls, Pakistani leprosy patients and tuberculosis patients in both the United Kingdom and Pakistan. This antigen has been described as M. leprae-specific, although it has a hypothetical homologue in M. tuberculosis. Human peripheral blood mononuclear cells were stimulated with peptide for 5 days and IFN-gamma measured in supernatants by ELISA. Some peptides were recognized more frequently by T cells from tuberculoid leprosy patients than those from UK controls, suggesting that such T cell epitopes might have diagnostic potential, while other peptides induced greater responses among UK control subjects. Short-term cell lines confirmed that these assays detected specific T cell recognition of these peptides. However, many tuberculosis patients also recognized these potentially specific peptides suggesting that there could be a true homologue present in M. tuberculosis.
Article.ArticleTitle: Human T cell responses to peptides of the Mycobacterium leprae 45-kD serine-rich antigen.
Article.Affiliations: Immunology Unit, Department of Infectious and Tropical Diseases, London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, London, UK.
Article.ArticleChemicalList: Antigens, Bacterial;Epitopes, T-Lymphocyte;HLA-DR Antigens;Immunodominant Epitopes;Mycobacterium leprae 45 kDa antigen;Peptides;Serine;Interferon-gamma
Article.ArticleMeshHeadingsList: Amino Acid Sequence; Antigens, Bacterial(chemistry; immunology); Cell Line; Cells, Cultured; Epitopes, T-Lymphocyte(chemistry; immunology); HLA-DR Antigens(metabolism); Humans; Immunodominant Epitopes(chemistry; immunology); Interferon-gamma(biosynthesis); Leprosy, Tuberculoid(immunology); Molecular Sequence Data; Molecular Weight; Mycobacterium leprae(immunology); Pakistan; Peptides(immunology); Sequence Homology, Amino Acid; Serine(chemistry); T-Lymphocytes(immunology); Tuberculosis, Pulmonary(immunology); United Kingdom(ethnology)

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Patients were diagnosed and classified by standard clinical and bacteriological parameters and all had BCG scars. All the patients were in the early stages of multi drug therapy (less than 4 weeks' treatment) and none had a previous history of tuberculosis or other diseases.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: PBMC from 20% of TT/BT leprosy patients tested (n=15) had IFNg production after 5 day-stimulation with the epitope versus 65% of healthy controls.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: A short term CD3 + cell line was derived from healthy donor PBMC by stimulation with the epitope for 14 days. Autologous macrophages presenting the epitope were added to the cell line for 3 days and IFNg measured by ELISA.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: PBMC from 65% of healthy donors tested (n=20) had IFNg production after 5 day-stimulation with the epitope versus 20% in leprosy patients. 10 out of 11 responders had DR 1,4,7,1404, or 17. 5 out of 6 non-responders also had these alleles.
PBMC from 5% of healthy donors tested (n=20) had IFNg production after stimulation by the epitope versus 13% with leprosy patients.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Patients were diagnosed and classified by standard clinical and bacteriological parameters and all had BCG scars. All the patients were in the early stages of multi drug therapy (less than 4 weeks' treatment) and none had a previous history of tuberculosis or other diseases.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: 50% of PBMC from leprosy patients produced IFNg after 5 days in culture with the epitope versus 5% with control PBMC.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Donors were pulmonary TB patients recruited in UK (n=6) or in Pakistan (n=16). All were on antituberculosis therapy.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: PBMC from 44% of Pakistan and 17% of UK tuberculosis patients produced IFNg after 5 days in culture with the epitope versus 5% of healthy controls.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: A short term CD3 + cell line was derived from healthy donor PBMC by stimulation with the epitope for 14 days. Autologous macrophages presenting the epitope were added to the cell line for 3 days and IFNg measured by ELISA.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: 5% of PBMC from healthy donors produced IFNg after 5 days in culture with the epitope versus 50% with PBMC from leprosy patients.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Patients were diagnosed and classified by standard clinical and bacteriological parameters and all had BCG scars. All the patients were in the early stages of multi drug therapy (less than 4 weeks' treatment) and none had a previous history of tuberculosis or other diseases.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: PBMC from 13% of TT/BT leprosy patients tested (n=15) had IFNg production after 5 day-stimulation with the epitope versus 5% of healthy controls (n=20). 8 out of 13 non-responders had DR 1, 4, 7, or 17 (the predicted binding alleles), while 0 out of 2 responders had none of these alleles.
5% of PBMC from healthy donors produced IFNg after 5 days in culture with the epitope versus 56% with PBMC from leprosy patients.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Donors were pulmonary TB patients recruited in UK (n=6) or in Pakistan (n=16). All were on antituberculosis therapy.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: PBMC from 38% of Pakistan and 33% of UK tuberculosis patients produced IFNg after 5 days in culture with the epitope versus 5% of healthy controls.

PBMC from 10% of healthy donors tested (n=20) had IFNg production after stimulation by the epitope versus 40% with leprosy patients.
